Apple___Apple_scab.cause: Caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis, which thrives in cool, wet spring weather. It overwinters in infected leaves on the ground.
Apple___Apple_scab.prevention: Choose resistant apple varieties. Rake and destroy fallen leaves in autumn. Ensure good air circulation through proper pruning.
Apple___Apple_scab.treatment: Apply fungicides from the time of bud break until dry weather prevails. Common treatments include captan and sulfur-based fungicides.

Apple___Black_rot.cause: Caused by the fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa. The fungus infects dead tissue first and then moves into healthy wood, leaves, and fruit.
Apple___Black_rot.prevention: Prune out dead or cankered branches. Remove mummified fruit from the tree. Maintain tree health with proper watering and fertilization.
Apple___Black_rot.treatment: Fungicide sprays used for apple scab can also help control black rot. Ensure thorough coverage.

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.cause: Caused by the fungus Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae. It requires both an apple tree and a juniper/cedar tree to complete its life cycle.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.prevention: Remove nearby juniper and cedar trees if possible. Plant rust-resistant apple varieties. Apply preventative fungicides.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.treatment: Apply fungicides during the pink and petal-fall stages of apple blossom development. Myclobutanil and mancozeb are effective.

Apple___healthy.prevention: Maintain health with proper watering, balanced fertilization, and good air circulation through pruning.

Blueberry___healthy.prevention: Ensure acidic soil, consistent moisture, and use appropriate fertilizers for acid-loving plants.

Cherry_(including_sour)__Powdery_mildew.cause: Caused by the fungus Podosphaera clandestina, which thrives in humid conditions and moderate temperatures.
Cherry_(including_sour)__Powdery_mildew.prevention: Ensure good air circulation by pruning. Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer. Plant in sunny locations.
Cherry_(including_sour)__Powdery_mildew.treatment: Apply fungicides such as sulfur, potassium bicarbonate, or horticultural oils at the first sign of disease.

Cherry(including_sour)__healthy.prevention: Protect from birds with netting. Ensure good drainage and consistent watering.

Corn(maize)__Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_l.disease_name: Cercospora Leaf Spot / Gray Leaf Spot
Corn(maize)__Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_l.cause: Caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis. It survives in infected corn debris and thrives in warm, humid weather.
Corn(maize)__Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_l.prevention: Use resistant corn hybrids. Practice crop rotation with non-host crops. Use tillage to bury infected residue.
Corn(maize)__Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_l.treatment: Fungicide application can be effective if applied early, especially on susceptible hybrids in high-risk conditions.

Corn(maize)_Common_rust.cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi, which is spread by wind and thrives in humid weather with moderate temperatures.
Corn(maize)_Common_rust.prevention: Plant resistant hybrids. Most modern hybrids have good resistance.
Corn(maize)_Common_rust.treatment: Fungicide application is usually not economically necessary for common rust but can be used in severe cases.

Corn(maize)__Northern_Leaf_Blight.cause: Caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum. Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures.
Corn(maize)__Northern_Leaf_Blight.prevention: Plant resistant hybrids. Crop rotation and tillage are also effective at reducing inoculum.
Corn(maize)__Northern_Leaf_Blight.treatment: Fungicides can be effective, especially when applied at the first sign of disease on susceptible hybrids.

Corn(maize)healthy.prevention: Ensure adequate nitrogen supply and proper soil moisture, especially during tasseling.

Grape___Black_rot.cause: Caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii. It overwinters in mummified berries and cane lesions.
Grape___Black_rot.prevention: Remove and destroy all mummified berries and infected canes during dormancy. Promote good air circulation.
Grape___Black_rot.treatment: Apply fungicides on a regular schedule starting from early shoot growth until the berries begin to ripen. Mancozeb and myclobutanil are effective.

Grape___Esca(Black_Measles).cause: A complex disease caused by a group of wood-infecting fungi. Infection often occurs through pruning wounds.
Grape___Esca(Black_Measles).prevention: Avoid pruning in the rain. Apply pruning wound protectants. Remove and destroy infected vines.
Grape___Esca(Black_Measles).treatment: There is no cure for Esca. Management focuses on surgical removal of infected parts of the vine and promoting overall plant health.

Grape___Leaf_blight(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot.cause: Caused by the fungus Pseudocercospora vitis. The disease is favored by warm, humid weather.
Grape___Leaf_blight(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot.prevention: Promote good air circulation through leaf pulling and canopy management. Destroy fallen leaves.
Grape___Leaf_blight(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot.treatment: Fungicides used for other grape diseases like black rot will also control leaf blight.

Grape___healthy.prevention: Use a proper trellis system. Prune annually during dormancy. Ensure good sun exposure and air movement.

Orange___Haunglongbing(Citrus_greening).cause: Caused by a bacterium transmitted by the Asian citrus psyllid, an insect. It is one of the most destructive citrus diseases.
Orange___Haunglongbing(Citrus_greening).prevention: Control psyllid populations with insecticides. Remove and destroy infected trees to reduce the spread. Use certified disease-free nursery stock.
Orange___Haunglongbing(Citrus_greening).treatment: There is currently no cure for Citrus Greening. Management focuses on prevention and slowing the spread.

Peach___Bacterial_spot.cause: Caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. pruni. Favored by warm, wet weather.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Plant resistant varieties. Avoid overhead irrigation. Maintain tree vigor with balanced fertilization.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Copper-based bactericides can be used, but timing is critical. They should be applied late in the dormant season or after petal fall.

Peach___healthy.prevention: Prune in late winter to shape the tree and remove dead wood. Thin fruit to encourage larger, healthier peaches.

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.cause: Caused by Xanthomonas bacteria. Spread by splashing water, tools, and hands. Thrives in warm, humid conditions.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Use disease-free seeds and transplants. Rotate crops. Avoid working with plants when they are wet. Use mulch to reduce water splash.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Copper-based bactericides can slow the spread but will not cure infected plants. Remove heavily infected plants.

Pepper,_bell___healthy.prevention: Provide consistent moisture. Support plants with stakes or cages. Ensure well-drained soil rich in organic matter.

Potato___Early_blight.cause: Caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. It survives in infected plant debris and soil.
Potato___Early_blight.prevention: Use certified disease-free seed potatoes. Rotate crops. Ensure good nutrition to maintain plant vigor.
Potato___Early_blight.treatment: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb on a preventative schedule, especially during periods of high humidity.

Potato___Late_blight.cause: Caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans. It is highly destructive and spreads rapidly in cool, moist conditions.
Potato___Late_blight.prevention: Use certified disease-free seed. Destroy volunteer potato plants. Allow for good air circulation. Apply preventative fungicides.
Potato___Late_blight.treatment: At the first sign of disease, apply targeted fungicides and shorten the spray interval. Destroy infected foliage before harvesting to prevent tuber infection.

Potato___healthy.prevention: 'Hill' the soil around the plants to protect developing tubers from sunlight and pests.

Raspberry___healthy.prevention: Prune canes after fruiting. Use a trellis to support canes and improve air circulation.

Soybean___healthy.prevention: Ensure proper planting depth and spacing. Use crop rotation to manage soil-borne diseases.

Squash___Powdery_mildew.cause: Caused by several different species of fungi. Thrives in both high humidity and dry conditions.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.prevention: Plant resistant varieties. Ensure good air circulation and sun exposure. Avoid overhead watering.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.treatment: Apply horticultural oils, sulfur, or potassium bicarbonate at the first sign of disease. Many commercial fungicides are also available.

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.cause: Caused by the fungus Diplocarpon earlianum. Favored by wet conditions.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.prevention: Plant in well-drained soil. Use mulch to keep leaves dry. Remove old, infected leaves after harvest.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.treatment: Apply fungicides during periods of rapid leaf growth in the spring. Captan is a common option.

Strawberry___healthy.prevention: Renovate beds after harvest. Protect from frost during flowering. Use straw mulch to keep fruit clean.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.cause: Caused by Xanthomonas bacteria. Spreads in warm, wet conditions and can be introduced via infected seed.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.prevention: Use disease-free seed. Rotate crops. Mulch plants to reduce water splashing. Avoid overhead irrigation.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Copper-based sprays can help limit the spread but will not cure the plant. Remove infected leaves.

Tomato___Early_blight.cause: Caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. It often affects the lower, older leaves first and is favored by humidity.
Tomato___Early_blight.prevention: Ensure good air circulation. Mulch heavily. Water at the base of the plant. Rotate crops.
Tomato___Early_blight.treatment: Prune off infected lower leaves. Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb as a preventative measure.

Tomato___Late_blight.cause: Caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans. It is highly destructive and spreads rapidly in cool, moist conditions.
Tomato___Late_blight.prevention: Use resistant varieties. Allow for ample spacing between plants. Water soil, not leaves. Monitor local disease forecasts.
Tomato___Late_blight.treatment: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately. Preventative fungicide application is key. Copper fungicides and chlorothalonil are common treatments.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.cause: Caused by the fungus Passalora fulva. It is most common in greenhouses with high humidity and poor air circulation.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.prevention: Use resistant varieties. Ensure good ventilation and low humidity. Stake plants to improve air flow.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.treatment: Apply fungicides at the first sign of disease. Remove infected leaves and plant debris.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.cause: Caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici. Spores are spread by splashing water.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.prevention: Water at the base of the plant. Use mulch. Rotate crops. Remove infected leaves promptly.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.treatment: Fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper can be effective if applied early and regularly.

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.cause: Infestation by tiny arachnids (Tetranychus urticae). They thrive in hot, dry conditions and feed on plant cells.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.prevention: Keep plants well-watered. Increase humidity. Regularly inspect the undersides of leaves.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.treatment: Spray plants with a strong jet of water to dislodge them. Apply insecticidal soap or horticultural oil. Introduce natural predators like ladybugs.

Tomato___Target_Spot.cause: Caused by the fungus Corynespora cassiicola. Thrives in high humidity and warm temperatures.
Tomato___Target_Spot.prevention: Improve air circulation. Avoid overhead watering. Remove infected plant debris from the garden.
Tomato___Target_Spot.treatment: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Prune affected leaves to slow the spread.

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.cause: A virus transmitted by the silverleaf whitefly. It causes stunting, yellowing, and upward curling of leaves.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.prevention: Use resistant tomato varieties. Control whitefly populations using reflective mulch, insecticides, or insect netting.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.treatment: There is no cure for the virus. Infected plants should be removed and destroyed to prevent further spread by whiteflies.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.cause: A virus that can be spread mechanically by hands, tools, and contact between plants. It can persist in soil and on seeds.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.prevention: Wash hands thoroughly before handling plants. Use virus-resistant varieties. Do not use tobacco products near tomato plants.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.treatment: There is no cure. Infected plants should be removed and destroyed to prevent spread.

Tomato___healthy.prevention: Provide support with stakes or cages. Ensure consistent watering and use a balanced fertilizer.
